body: Right, so: can you try to use the torch17_backend when using torch <=1.7 and otherwise torch_backend when torch >1.7 (sorry for this situation, it's not us..) Does it fix your issue?

@edouardoyallon If you mean `backend='torch'` with `torch 1.7.1`, the error persists. If it helps, Win 10 x64, Python 3.7.9.

Btw I'm mainly reporting for your notice, my use is primarily with studying the code; got tripped with `cupy.util`, but fine otherwise.

Can you try to use backend='torch17_skcuda'?
https://github.com/kymatio/kymatio/pull/679/files#diff-09dede65a58346e201c282dd2ce84d02b0c3bf73ed7d2ce766399a8992ed14e4

`backend='torch17_skcuda'` yields
output ```python D:\Anaconda\envs\pyt\lib\site-packages\kymatio\scattering1d\backend\torch17_skcuda_backend.py:12: UserWarning: The function torch.fft is deprecated and will be removed in PyTorch 1.8. Use the new torch.fft module functions, instead, by importing torch.fft and calling torch.fft.fft or torch.fft.fftn. (Triggered internally at ..\aten\src\ATen\native\SpectralOps.cpp:567.) fft = FFT(lambda x: torch.fft(x, 1, normalized=False), Traceback (most recent call last): File "C:\untitled10.py", line 19, in Scx = scattering(xt) File "D:\Anaconda\envs\pyt\lib\site-packages\torch\nn\modules\module.py", line 727, in _call_impl result = self.forward(*input, **kwargs) File "D:\Anaconda\envs\pyt\lib\site-packages\kymatio\frontend\torch_frontend.py", line 23, in forward return self.scattering(x) File "D:\Anaconda\envs\pyt\lib\site-packages\kymatio\scattering1d\frontend\torch_frontend.py", line 121, in scattering out_type=self.out_type) File "D:\Anaconda\envs\pyt\lib\site-packages\kymatio\scattering1d\core\scattering1d.py", line 84, in scattering1d S_0_c = cdgmm(U_0_hat, phi[0]) File "D:\Anaconda\envs\pyt\lib\site-packages\kymatio\backend\torch_backend.py", line 193, in cdgmm raise TypeError('Input and filter must be of the same dtype.') TypeError: Input and filter must be of the same dtype. ```
Also just upgraded to `pytorch 1.8.0`, all errors the same (but didn't test master branch)
A bit of help with the PR(s) would be welcome, the team (including myself) is a bit overwhelmed with work - if u need access to my repo, lmk

I'll it consider once time-freq scattering's ready for a vectorized 1D port. For one I'd suggest not supporting both `<=` and `>` pytorch versions, instead just requiring users to upgrade, since with PyTorch I don't think there's much reason not to, and supporting both can get quite messy.

> with PyTorch I don't think there's much reason not to

Apart from the current slow-down using the complex number type, of which I don't know what exactly could be causing it. Maybe @edouardoyallon  you now have some insight into this?

@eickenberg Slower how? I just tested `fft`, multiplication, addition, and division of `complex64` and `complex128`, 1.7.1 vs 1.8.0, not seeing a difference. Win 10 x64, GTX 1070.

<details>
  <summary>bench code</summary>

```python
import torch
import torch.fft as tfft
from timeit import timeit

def timer(fn, number=100):
    print(timeit(fn, number=number) / number)

x = torch.randn((300, 240000), dtype=torch.complex128, device='cuda') * (1 + 2j)
timer(lambda: tfft.fft(x, dim=-1))
timer(lambda: x * (2 - 1j) / (x**1.5 + 1))
```
</details>

> Thanks for running that benchmark.
> @edouardoyallon do you remember what caused a slow-down when benching complex numbers?
> Maybe it is something that happened on the release candidate but not on the release?

I'd love to run automatically a proper benchmark using asv. I'd like to isolate the slow part.
